title: Jewish writers boycotted during Israel - Hamas war - The Jerusalem Post
message:
Does this little slice of the literary world even matter?It does.
The anti-Israel sentiment in the literary world could have a searing effect on Jewish literature.
But Jewish authors are still feeling unsafe.
They are endangering that which the literary world is supposed to hold most dear: the free exchange of ideas.
In a literary world allegedly dedicated to free speech, what great works of literature will be lost with this censorship?

title: Columbia University alumnus donates $260 million to Israeli university
message:
A Columbia grad who was 'active in World War II' has donated $260 million to Israel's Bar-Ilan University.
Both gifts were made in the face of fierce pro-Palestine processions that have surfaced across the US over the past several months.
A Columbia grad who was 'active in World War II' has donated $260 million to Israel's Bar-Ilan University.
It’s just the beginning,' added political Hank Sheinkopf, offering the insight to the famously pro Israel New York Post.
'Dear university students in the United States of America, you are standing on the right side of history.'

title: Anti - Palestinian discrimination investigation opens at UNC following complaint
message:
Khalili wrote that this email failed to acknowledge Israel's violence against Palestinians and address Islamophobia or Palestinians by name, while it did address antisemitism and Israel.

title: Terrorism and the Israel - Palestine conflict
message:
The history of the Israel-Palestine conflict makes clear that we have not learned from the horrors of the past, Dermot Daley writes.
The world recoiled at the use of explosives on civilian targets within the UK to create fear and awe.
When, in 1948, a new Jewish State was created in Palestine – as with the 1917 Balfour Declaration – the existing populace was not consulted.
Politicians have rushed forward to claim that the actions of Hamas and the IDF cannot be compared.
We urgently need to redefine what constitutes terrorism and we must wash the blood off our hands and publicly step up as defenders of true justice.

title: Community rallies for A . S . divestment resolution with market and march
message:
The efforts preluded a vote within the Associated Student Senate on a divestment resolution, rallying campus support for the University to cut ties to military contractors.
“The People’s Market for Gaza” took place from 4-5 p.m. at People’s Park in Isla Vista with roughly 50 attendees.
From People’s Park, organizers lead a procession of roughly 100 people toward the front of Embarcadero Hall.
Protestors chanted at the guests, “Students, students we won’t rest, until UCSB Divests,” before continuing to Loma Pelona Center for the Senate meeting.
Event organizers gave instructions to event participants to sign up for public comment for the Senate meeting that night where senators would vote on a divestment resolution.

title: Chicago truck driver raises awareness for friend held hostage in Gaza
message:
“I always know that.”Twelve hours a day, six days a week, Smith drives the truck through the Chicago area, raising awareness for the scores of Israeli hostages held captive by Hamas.
To Smith, he’s like a brother.
“I wouldn’t want nobody else to drive the truck,” Smith said, clutching the Star of David around his neck.
Hersh’s family had no idea if he was alive until April 24, when Hamas released a three-minute video of him in captivity.
“But I’m just here to spread awareness about all the hostages.”The truck was concocted by Jeff Aeder, a close friend of Hersh’s family.
